body_html:
This is how cond works, here's some explanation -- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37063952/confused-by-the-behavior-of-tf-cond/37064128#37064128

Basically it's how TensorFlow runtime works:

  • increase_tfvar_op is a dependency of f1
  • f1 and f2 are dependencies of cond
  • therefore increase_tfvar_op is a dependency of cond

Dependencies must be computed before tf.cond is ready to execute. It's smart enough to figure out that f1 doesn't need to be executed, but not smart enough to figure out that increase_tfvar_op doesn't need to be.

Dependencies must be computed before tf.cond is ready to execute. It's smart enough to figure out that f1 doesn't need to be executed, but not smart enough to figure out that increase_tfvar_op doesn't need to be.
body:
This is how cond works, here's some explanation -- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37063952/confused-by-the-behavior-of-tf-cond/37064128#37064128

Basically it's how TensorFlow runtime works:
- increase_tfvar_op is a dependency of f1
- f1 and f2 are dependencies of cond
- therefore increase_tfvar_op is a dependency of cond

Dependencies must be computed before tf.cond is ready to execute. It's smart enough to figure out that f1 doesn't need to be executed, but not smart enough to figure out that increase_tfvar_op doesn't need to be.
